22: According to the resolution, what is the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention for proposing amendments to the Constitution?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention for proposing amendments to the Constitution is as follows:

According to Article V of the Constitution, Congress must call a Convention for proposing amendments if two-thirds of the states apply for it. The resolution states that there have been 34 continuing applications for a Convention to propose amendments on the single issue of fiscal responsibility, which meets the two-thirds requirement.

Additionally, the resolution states that the Convention shall be ratified by a vote of We the People in three-quarters of the states (38 states) via State Convention delegates.

Therefore, the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention for proposing amendments to the Constitution is the submission of applications from two-thirds of the states (34 states) on the single issue of fiscal responsibility, and the ratification of the proposed amendments by three-quarters of the states (38 states) via State Convention delegates.
What is the basis for the resolution's call for a Convention for proposing amendments, as stated in the resolution's preamble?

The basis for the resolution's call for a Convention for proposing amendments, as stated in the resolution's preamble, is the fact that Article V of the Constitution of the United States states that Congress shall call a Convention for proposing amendments to the Constitution on the application of the legislatures of two-thirds of the several States. The preamble references the fact that congressional and state records show that there have been applications for amendments on the subject of inflation-fighting fiscal responsibility from 34 states, thereby achieving the two-thirds congressional mandate to call the Convention. The preamble also references Alexander Hamilton's statement in Federalist 85 that Congress shall call a Convention, and the fact that the Constitution was ratified by convention delegates chosen by the people of each state. Finally, the preamble references the Supreme Court's unanimous opinion in Chiafalo v. Washington, which states that electors have no ground for reversing the vote of millions of citizens, and that the direction of the Constitution accords with the trust of the nation that We the People rule.
What is the exception to the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention, as stated in the resolution?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the exception to the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention is as follows:

"Paragraph (1) does not apply if, prior to the expiration of the 60-day period which begins on the date of the adoption of this concurrent resolution—

(A) the House Clerk provides a written report stating there have never been unrescinded and continuing applications for a Convention to propose amendments from at least two-thirds (34) of the States on any national issues (plenary) plus the single issue of fiscal responsibility; and

(B) the House Clerk includes in the report detailed findings for each State."

In other words, if the House Clerk provides a report stating that there have never been unrescinded and continuing applications for a Convention to propose amendments from at least two-thirds of the States on any national issues, including the single issue of fiscal responsibility, then the requirement for Congress to call an Article V Convention is waived.
What is the requirement for the ratification of amendments proposed at the Convention, as stated in the resolution?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the requirement for the ratification of amendments proposed at the Convention is a vote of We the People in three-quarters (38) of the States via State Convention delegates. This is stated in section (b) of the resolution, which quotes the Supreme Court's unanimous opinion in Chiafalo v. Washington: "Each proposed amendment at the Convention for proposing amendments called under this section shall be ratified by a vote of We the People in three-quarters (38) of the States via State Convention delegates who shall have no ground for reversing the vote of millions of its citizens."

72: What does Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibit?

Based solely on the reference material provided, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 prohibits sex discrimination in all educational programs and activities that receive Federal assistance, including athletics programs. It does not confine the list of those liable under the statute to recipients of Federal funds, but simply prohibits discrimination under any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance. The resolution also states that the NCAA exercises controlling authority over its federally funded member institutions' athletics programs and is therefore subject to title IX.
What does the reference text state about the scope of entities subject to Title IX?

Based solely on the reference text, the following is stated about the scope of entities subject to Title IX:

1. Title IX applies to all educational programs and activities that receive Federal assistance, including athletics programs.
2. The list of entities subject to Title IX is not limited to recipients of Federal funds, but rather prohibits discrimination under any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.
3. The Department of Education's implementing regulations for Title IX require educational programs to offer students of all sexes equal opportunities to play sports, allocate athletic scholarships equitably, and treat athletes of all sexes equally with respect to other benefits and services.
4. The definition of a program or activity that receives Federal funds under Title IX is broad and includes all of the operations of colleges and universities, private organizations principally engaged in education, and any other entity established by two or more of the listed entities.
5. Federal courts have held that State athletic associations and the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) exercise controlling authority over interscholastic athletics programs and are therefore subject to Title IX, regardless of whether they are themselves recipients of Federal aid.
6.
According to the reference text, what is the definition of "program or activity" under Title IX?

Based solely on the reference material above, the definition of "program or activity" under Title IX is:

"all of the operations of a list of entities, including colleges and universities, private organizations principally engaged in education, and any other entity established by 2 or more of the listed entities."

This definition is found in section 908 of the Education Amendments of 1972, which broadly defines a program or activity that receives Federal funds to include all of the operations of the listed entities.
What is the significance of the catch-all provision in Section 908 of the Education Amendments of 1972?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the significance of the catch-all provision in Section 908 of the Education Amendments of 1972 is that it broadly defines a "program or activity" that receives Federal funds to include all of the operations of entities such as colleges and universities, private organizations principally engaged in education, and any other entity established by two or more of the listed entities. This catch-all provision allows for the application of title IX to entities that may not be direct recipients of Federal aid but still exercise controlling authority over federally funded programs. The provision is significant because it ensures that any entity that exercises controlling authority over a federally funded program is subject to title IX, regardless of whether it is itself a recipient of Federal aid. This includes the National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA), which is subject to title IX because it is an organization established by two or more colleges or universities that receive Federal funds, and it exercises controlling authority over its member institutions' athletics programs.
What is the basis for the argument that the NCAA is subject to Title IX?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the argument that the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) is subject to Title IX is based on the following grounds:

1. The NCAA exercises controlling authority over its member institutions' athletics programs, just like State athletic associations.
2. The NCAA is an organization established by two or more colleges or universities that receive Federal funds, pursuant to section 908 of the Education Amendments of 1972.
3. The NCAA is an operation of its federally funded member schools, pursuant to section 908 of such Act.
4. Federal courts have held that State athletic associations exercise controlling authority over interscholastic athletics programs and are therefore subject to Title IX, and the same reasoning applies to the NCAA.
5. Not subjecting the NCAA to Title IX would encourage Federal recipients to empower someone else to promulgate discriminatory policies to avoid Title IX liability, which would allow Federal funds to promote sex discrimination and run afoul of the plain language, meaning, and purpose of Title IX.
What is the issue of NCAA v. Smith (1999) regarding Title IX?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the issue of NCAA v. Smith (1999) regarding Title IX is whether the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) is subject to Title IX, a federal law that prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex in education programs and activities that receive federal assistance. The Supreme Court ruled in the case that the NCAA is not subject to Title IX based on the dues it receives from its federally funded member schools, but left open the question of whether the NCAA is subject to Title IX on alternative grounds, including based on its controlling authority over member schools' federally funded athletics programs.

98: What is the specific line item veto authority being proposed for the President in this resolution?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the specific line item veto authority being proposed for the President in this resolution is the ability to reduce an appropriation in a bill or joint resolution that is presented to the President for approval under section 7 of article I of the Constitution. The President may reduce an appropriation in such a bill or joint resolution, and the bill or joint resolution shall become law with the reduction incorporated. The President must notify the House of Representatives and the Senate of the reduction within 10 days, and the House of Representatives and the Senate may consider disapproval of the reduction. If two-thirds of each House votes to disapprove of the reduction, the amount of the appropriation in law subject to the reduction shall be treated as returned to the amount originally presented to the President.
According to the resolution, what is the time frame for the President to notify Congress of any reductions made under this authority?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the President must notify Congress of any reductions made under this authority within 10 days after the date of the reduction. This is stated in section 2 of the proposed amendment, which states: "Not later than 10 days after the date of such reduction, the President shall notify the House of Representatives and the Senate of such reduction."
How does the resolution provide for Congressional disapproval of any reductions made by the President?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the resolution provides for Congressional disapproval of any reductions made by the President as follows:

1. The President must notify the House of Representatives and the Senate of any reductions made under section 1 of the resolution within 10 days of the reduction.
2. The House of Representatives and the Senate may consider disapproval of such reduction.
3. If two-thirds of each House votes to disapprove of the reduction, the amount of the appropriation in law subject to the reduction shall be treated as returned to the amount originally presented to the President under section 1.

In other words, the resolution allows Congress to disapprove of any reductions made by the President by a two-thirds vote in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. If Congress disapproves of the reduction, the amount of the appropriation in law will be treated as if it had not been reduced.
What is the effect on the appropriation if two-thirds of both the House of Representatives and the Senate vote to disapprove of a reduction made by the President?

Based solely on the reference material provided, if two-thirds of both the House of Representatives and the Senate vote to disapprove of a reduction made by the President, the amount of the appropriation in law subject to such reduction shall be treated as returned to the amount originally presented to the President under section 1.

What is the definition of a "consecutive term" in the context of this proposed amendment, according to section 2?

Based solely on the reference material provided, a "consecutive term" in the context of the proposed amendment refers to a period of time during which an individual serves as a Senator or Representative without interruption. Specifically, section 2 of the proposed amendment states that no person who has been a Representative for six consecutive terms shall again be eligible for election to the House of Representatives until the first day of the second Congress that begins after the sixth consecutive term. How is the length of time for which a person fills a vacancy in the Senate or House of Representatives determined, according to section 3?

Based solely on the reference material provided, the length of time for which a person fills a vacancy in the Senate or House of Representatives is determined as follows:

According to section 3 of the joint resolution, any term a person serves as a Senator or Representative to fill a vacancy shall not be included in determining the number of consecutive terms that the person has been a Senator or Representative unless the period of time for which the person fills the vacancy is greater than three years in the case of a Senator or greater than one year in the case of a Representative.

Therefore, if a person fills a vacancy in the Senate or House of Representatives for a period of time that is less than three years (in the case of a Senator) or one year (in the case of a Representative), that time will not be counted as a consecutive term for the purpose of determining eligibility for future service in the same office.
Are there any exceptions to the limitation on consecutive terms for Senators and Representatives, according to the text? If so, what are they?

2. Terms beginning before the date of ratification: According to section 4 of the proposed amendment, any term that began before the date of the ratification of this article shall not be included in determining the number of consecutive terms that a person has been a Senator or Representative.
